Literature Review: The transition towards sustainable chemical manufacturing has become a pivotal area of research, with electrochemical synthesis emerging as a promising pathway to reduce the carbon footprint of the chemical industry. This literature review focuses on the electrochemical manufacturing routes for organic chemical commodities, highlighting the potential of this technology to utilize renewable electricity and abundant carbon feedstocks for the production of key petrochemical precursors and basic organic chemical products. The review is structured around three main themes: the identification of feasible electrochemical routes, the overcoming of technological challenges, and the strategies for large-scale implementation. Electrochemical synthesis offers a unique opportunity to decarbonize the production of light olefins, olefin oxidation derivatives, aromatics, and methanol by directly utilizing renewable electricity. Studies have demonstrated the feasibility of converting CO2 and water into methanol through electrochemical reduction, showcasing the potential for significant reductions in greenhouse gas emissions (Olah et al., 2009). Similarly, the electrochemical production of ethylene from CO2 has been explored, with recent advancements in catalyst design leading to improved selectivity and efficiency (Jouny et al., 2018). The production of aromatics through electrochemical routes, although less explored, presents an intriguing avenue for the synthesis of benzene, toluene, and xylene from biomass-derived intermediates (Zhang et al., 2017). Despite these advancements, several technological challenges hinder the widespread adoption of electrochemical manufacturing routes. Key among these is the development of catalysts that can operate at high production rates, selectivity, and stability. Recent research has focused on the design of nanostructured catalysts and the optimization of reaction conditions to enhance the performance of electrochemical reactors (Koper, 2013). Additionally, the integration of electrochemical processes with renewable energy sources requires the development of efficient energy storage and conversion systems to ensure a stable and continuous supply of electricity (Schiffer & Manthiram, 2017). To achieve large-scale electrochemical manufacturing of organic chemical commodities, a multidisciplinary approach is necessary. This includes the development of scalable reactor designs, the establishment of supply chains for renewable feedstocks, and the implementation of policies that support the transition towards electrified chemical production (Bard & Faulkner, 2001). Furthermore, the economic viability of electrochemical routes must be assessed in comparison to conventional thermochemical processes, taking into account the potential for cost reductions through technological advancements and economies of scale (Hori, 2008). In conclusion, electrochemical synthesis represents a transformative approach to the production of organic chemical commodities, offering a pathway to significantly reduce the environmental impact of the chemical industry. However, realizing this potential requires continued innovation in catalysis and reaction engineering, as well as the development of strategies for large-scale implementation. The integration of electrochemical processes with renewable energy sources and the establishment of supportive policy frameworks will be critical to the successful electrification and decarbonization of chemical manufacturing.
